segments.text: Three, two, one.
Tape interview, Donald Ouellette interviewing Hoyt Haddock, December 23, 1982, Washington, DC.
Mr. Haddock, could you please give me some general biographical background as to your date of birth?
Well, I was born May 5, 1907.
on a farm about four miles from Boyd, Texas.
That's in Wise County.
Decatur is the county seat.
And my father was a sharecropper, and we lived on the farm until
Oh, I guess, as I remember, we moved from a farm to Decatur and lived in Decatur a while.
Then we moved from Decatur to Greenwood, back on another farm, and then from Greenwood to Lubbock, Lubbock back to Fort Worth, where I really grew up.
I lived in Fort Worth until I left there in 1927 to go to Galveston to take a ship.
In Fort Worth I went to, well, may as well tell you about the schooling I didn't have.
I finished grade school and I think it was in the tenth grade of high school when I quit high school for economic reasons.
Basically, I didn't have shoes to wear or clothes to wear to school.
I quit, quit there, quit school and took a job at Armour and Company in their fancy meat cooler.
I was a, my job was called box boy.
I put boxes together and then put lids on them when they would fill them up with the fancy meats, fancy meats being tongues and livers and hearts and this sort of thing, the various organs.
That job petered out because of the economic conditions then prevalent in the area.
and I got a job at Montgomery Wards.
There I was a stockman for several divisions before I left there.
Again, I was laid off because of economic conditions.
This was about in the mid-20s, and I guess
The economic conditions in Texas were worse than anywhere in the country at the time.
I can recall my father going literally for two years without a day's work.
He was a cabinetmaker.
He also did some contracting and carpenter work.
He'd do anything he could get to do.
Things were that bad in Texas at that time.
As I recall, this was about 1922 or 23 when he was out of work for so long.
So we've seen some hard times on the farm and off the farm.
The last farm that we were on was the one in Greenwood.
We had 100 acres, and practically the whole 100 acres were put in cotton.
and I guess for the first time the family got out of debt on that cotton because it was during a war time, World War I, and cotton prices went up and did pretty good on it.
In Fort Worth, after getting laid off from Brantley, from
Montgomery Wards.
I had gotten interested in radio and decided I wanted to be a radio operator on a ship.
So I went to Bratley Drawn, which was a commercial school, private school, and took radio for the purpose of getting my commercial radio officers, radio operators license, it was called at that time,
And after having gotten that, I went to Galveston and shipped out.
My first ship was in December the 27th.
I think 1927.
I'm not sure of that date.
I'll have to check that date.
I have it at home.
And I relieved someone who wanted to be home for Christmas.
And I stayed on the Tilly Likes until I really don't know how long.
But the company wanted me to take the West Comac.
This was a government ship operated by Likes Brothers, shipping board that was called at that time, the government agency.
And I took that ship west come back and spent a little time on her.
And I don't remember whether I got off because the ship laid up or for what reason now.
But I went from there to the ER camp of the Sinclair Navigation Company, Sinclair Refining.
And from that ship I came ashore as a radio operator at WPA, Port Arthur, Texas.

It's a station that was originally built by the Gulf Refining Company but later taken over by the Radio Marine Corporation of America as a result of a contract they made with the Gulf to furnish their radio equipment and service it and so forth.
And I was there until
Shipping really went bad.
About 50% of the ships got tied up, and the station had to cut back on its personnel.
And I shipped out again on a Gulf tanker for a few months.
I don't remember how long.
And then Port Arthur wanted me back, and I came back to Port Arthur.
And I stayed there until 1933.
In 1930, I had been soliciting members, getting radio officers to join the American Radio Telegraphist Association, of which I became a member.
This was a union of radio operators.
What was it?
Did it have a national affiliation?
No affiliation.
American Radio Telegraphist Association.
And they asked me to run for president, and I told them that I would run for president, provided the
they would let me stay in Port Arthur because I didn't want to act as, didn't want an active presidency in the Union.
And I didn't want to go to New York.
So, 1931, there was an election.
I was elected president.
They counted the ballots at night and sent me a telegram, which I got the next morning.

long telegram telling me that the, if I wanted a union, I'd better come to New York and take over because the then secretary treasurer had not been in the office in six or seven weeks and was frequently seen drunk in the gutter in New York.
And they didn't think that he would ever be able to keep the union together.
So I, my wife and I packed our stuff and we went to, got in our little Ford and drove up to New York.
And I became an active unionist at that time.
I became president, in fact.
And interesting enough, when I got to New York, there were 31 paid up members of the union.
And I stayed with the Union until 1937 and I'm told the membership at least a year ahead of that that I did not want to run again for presidency.
That I wanted to stay in the industry and I wanted to do other things.
Actually, I had set a
timetable on what I wanted to do.
I had wanted to go to sea for two years.
Then I had wanted to come ashore for three or four years as an operator in a coastal station.
Incidentally, while I was at Port Arthur, I changed from an operator to maintenance and repair and installation.
In other words, installing radio equipment
electronic equipment on ships, servicing it, maintaining it.
And after three or four years in that work, I wanted to become part of the Federal Communications Commission in Washington.
It wasn't the Federal Communications Commission then, it was the radio division of the Department of Commerce.
Anyway, that was the steps that I had
set out for myself to take.
Anyway, the union changed all of that.
I had not planned to be a trade unionist.
It wasn't in my schedule at all.
It was just one of these quirks in life that come along.
Anyway, in New York,
I became, of course, president of the American Radio-Telegraph Association, and that led into, of course, my association with the National Maritime Union.
In 1936, the, I think this was 36, I'm not sure of these dates, you'll have to check these dates against
material which you have.
These records will show the dates.
The famous California strike and them coming back to New York and trying to set up a viable trade union, which of course was fought
hand in tooth by the then International Seaman's Union's hierarchy, which were basically in cahoots with the steamship companies and not interested really in the membership.
The only thing they were interested in is controlling the membership so that they could make money.
Did you ever have any dealings with the presidents of the different divisions?
I had dealings with all of them.
We tried, of course, to get the cooperation of all of the maritime unions.
And we could get that cooperation as long as it was coming from us to them.
But the other way, we never got it from any of them, including the Longshoremen's Association at that time.
Joe Ryan was head of the Longshoremen's Association.
I can remember the first strike we had.
United States lines cut the wages of the radio operators on their ships a very large sum.
I don't remember what the figures were, but there was a very large cut in the wages of the radio operators.
This was when?
This would have been 1934 or 35.
I'm not sure when.
If you want those dates, you will have to try the American Radio Association office in New York for them because they would have all the back issues of the publications that we put out at that time.
It became apparent to me that we were probably going to have to strike
that company because we could not get a meeting with any of the officials of the United States lines.
So I sent out an invitation, a written invitation to all of the unions that I had any association with or thought should be involved in this because it was going to affect them.
for a meeting called at our then headquarters, which was 20 Irving Place in New York.
We addressed a letter to all of the divisions of the International Seaman's Union.
They had a stewards department, a deck department, and an engine department.
Then there was a
master mates and pilots, marine engineers, the ILA, of course, International Longshoremen's Association, and there was a Marine Workers Industrial Union, which was commie-controlled.
I did not know that at the time, but anyway, they were commie-controlled, and no
They didn't try to maintain it a secret.
They made it very plain the officers were communists.
They told me outright they were communists.
Anyway, I did invite them also because they were one of the unions in the maritime field.
And strange as it may seem, although I had frequent meetings with the ISU,
officials, and we were supposed to be cooperating, the only union that showed up willing to help us was this Marine Workers Industrial Union.
So, I laid out what I was, what I thought we ought to do, and they had some ideas on what should be done.
And anyway, we, we called a strike, and they were the only ones that really gave us any help in that strike.

The next, I guess the next really important thing in the marine field was then the California and it coming back to New York and them trying to set up a headquarters and it turned out that they could not rent a place for headquarters because everyone was putting in a plug against them.
If they found that they were about to rent some place, the company would call, call the
Steamship industry people would call up, and the old SIU unions and the ILA would call up the people who owned the place and tell them not to rent to that bunch of communists.
It turned out that I went and rented a place for them in the name of the ARA and got phones in.
It was American Radio Telegraph Association.
at that time and got telephones for them, which we paid for, and set up a headquarters for the strikers, the seamen.
Why would your union want to get involved with these striking factions?
Because it was perfectly plain to me that if we were going to have a union that meant anything, we were going to have to
worked with seamen who were interested in better conditions for the seafaring people.
Why do you think at this time, late 35, early 36, why all of a sudden were seamen getting involved in the unions again since the unions per se hadn't been strong since after the 1921 maritime strike?
Why all of a sudden 1935, 36?
Why did a large amount of seamen become politically active and union active?
Well, I think it was basically because this was really sort of an age of social conscience of people.
Not only seamen, but a lot of people.
became more social conscious, more conscious of the needs of the working people.
There was a movement of the whole population, really.
You will recall that in that time period,
The whole movement of liberals in the country started to try to help working people.
We had, of course, all of the government laws that were designed to help working people.
The National Labor Relations Act was an outgrowth of this whole thing.
There was a lot of labor legislation at that time.
And I think basically it was just, I can't pin it down to any one thing.
I just think there was a general awareness of the need of change amongst the population really.
Now what caused it, I don't know.
You can say it was the man up there or anything.
I don't know what it was.
I do know that something was guiding me because I was going where I had not planned to go at all.
So whether it was the man up there or what, I really don't know.
Because my schedule had not called for me to be active in trade union work.

my sole interest in getting involved in it in Port Arthur was to try to help to elevate the horrible conditions that did exist and of course when I got to New York to continue to work to eliminate those horrible conditions and getting
affiliated with the then, I guess you would call it, rebel group.
It was clear to me that if there was going to be any success in the trade union movement, it would have to be through the rebel group.
It was not coming from the corrupt, what I considered.
Then
I guess I shouldn't use the word corrupt because I can't prove that any of these people took money from anyone.
I guess I had better simply say that to me they did not display a concern for the people that they were elected to represent.
Why didn't your union, the ARTA, ever try to affiliate with the AFL?
We did.
We did try to affiliate, and they would not let us affiliate.
They insisted that we had to become part of the... Oh, what was the name of it?
Communication workers.
I can't think of the name of the union.
Again, I think there, I'm not sure that the union is still in existence, but you would have to get the name of it from the AFL-CIO.
I just don't remember the name of the old communication workers.
It's not the, not the communication workers of America.
It's the old
union that was affiliated with the AFL-CIO.
The communication workers of America came through the CIO.
So the AFL didn't want a maritime-based radio operators union.
They wanted to be affiliated with a land-based.
They insisted on that because that union had the charter for communication workers.
So they felt there'd be a jurisdictional boundary?
Oh, that union insisted that the AFLs not give a charter to us.
Retrogressing a bit back to the Marine Workers Industrial Union.
Right.
Why do you think it failed and the old ISU continued to survive from 34 on?
Basically, I think it failed because of its
communist affiliation.
I think that's the basic reason because basically, well basically Americans were not oriented towards dictatorships.
While the communists at that time of course preached that it was a dictatorship of the proletariat,
Anyone with very much sense had to soon learn that it was not a dictatorship of the proletariat, it was a dictatorship of the Communist Party.
And that the Communist Party, no totalitarian government can exist without having control over the workers.
Workers have to be slaves to the party in control or they can't maintain it.
And of course, the building of their armies and their power to maintain that control is power to control the working force.
That's basically the only way that they can stay in existence.
Moving back to the time when the California returned to New York after the strike in Pedro, who began to support the rebel faction besides your union?
Basically the Communists really were the only outward support there was.
There was plenty of liberal support, liberals in the New York area,

As a matter of fact, a lot of money was raised as a result of liberal help, people not affiliated with the communists who were liberals and recognized the need for changing the conditions which exist.
For example, I can remember a wife of one of the
presidents of one of the steamship companies giving a very large sum of money to this movement at that time to help the seamen.
And that was typical, you know, amongst a lot of fairly well-to-do liberal people who wanted to help.
But I really think that the Communists were not successful because
The people recognized that their allegiance was to the Communist Party, and the Communist Party was, at that time, the Communist Party of Russia.
Everything flowed back there.
The orders came down from there, and the orders went back there.
And I know that as far as Joe and I were concerned, Joe Curran,
We recognized that the Communists were only interested in building the unions for the purpose of building a power base for themselves.
They were really not interested in improving the conditions except for that purpose, to build a power base.
How early do you think Curran was aware of this, or became aware of this?
I would say from the first.
From the moment he arrived in New York?
or even earlier than that?
Well, I know that he and I started discussing this when immediately we got acquainted with each other.
When was the first time that you met Joe Curran?
I think the first time I met Joe Curran was in an apartment, in his apartment, in New York.
I think it was on 23rd, pardon me, 23rd Street.
I went to a meeting there that I was invited to.
I guess there were five or six of us in that meeting.
And I think that's the first time I met Joe, I'm not sure.
Before or after the California incident?
Well this was after.
I didn't know Joe.
You didn't know him before?
No.
This was after the California came back to New York and of course they were all dumped on the street and they started striking the ships.
And the men started piling off the ships.
The seamen needed someone to give them leadership, and Joe started providing that leadership.
Did Joe actively seek out this position as leader, or did it just happen that way?
It happened with Joe the same way it happened with me.
He had no idea of becoming an active president of a union.
This was the farthest from his thoughts.
All he wanted to do was to be a good member of Reunion and follow his calling as a seaman.
So you felt then, in 36, he just wanted to help reform the ISU and then go back to sea?
No.
I think once that he got in the leadership position that
he wanted to go back to sea.
I think that he wanted to stay in that position, that he wanted to continue that.
I didn't want to go back to sea to begin with.
I had no, two years was all I wanted to spend at sea, except as a first-class passenger.
The life of a seaman
did not fit my personality at all.
It's too restrictive.
You're a prisoner aboard that ship all the time you're at sea.
You have no, can't think of the right word, you have no intercourse with the political
economic and social life of the nation.
You see the same people at breakfast, dinner, and supper, and any recreation that you can
get started are with the same people.
And if there happen to be people on that ship who are not socially inclined, or what I would call for simplification, troublemakers, you have to see them every day in and out.
You cannot pick your friends.
Your friends are picked for you.
And it is just not a life that fits my personality.
There's a lot to be said for going to sea for someone who wants to spend a lot of time reading and educating himself, and I took advantage of that while I was at sea.
I found that that was the best outlet for me because I was not a gambler.
I did not play cards.
I did not drink.
And playing cards or checkers or something like that was about the only recreation at that time that existed on the ship.
But it is a good place to get yourself some self-education.
And goodness knows I needed plenty of it.
And I did take advantage of it.
I continued my mathematics.
It so happens that I was particularly good in mathematics when I got into high school.
And that's one of the things that I did continue.
Incidentally, we were graded at that time from 1 to 100, you know.
And in plane geometry, I believe it was plane geometry, I'm sure it was, we had a teacher.
And she gave us all a problem and said, now that anyone who can work that problem, I will give seven points extra on their report card.
Well, I had been getting 99 on my report card all along, so I wanted to see what happened.
So I worked the problem and brought it in, and I got the usual 99.
So I went to her and she said, well, Hoyt, you know that no one is perfect, and that's why I always give a 99 to anyone who passes all the tests and does the work in class.
as you have been doing it.
So if I give 106, which you would be entitled to, that means you're better than perfect, and that isn't so.
I said, well, that may not be so, but you promised me seven points, and I want them.
And if I don't get them, I'm going to the principal.
She said, well, I said, I understand your position.
And I'm not going to give them to you, and you're perfectly free to go to the principal.
So I went to the principal.
The principal ordered her to give me the seven points.
Stupid, but that's the way it happened anyway.
But I was particularly interested in that, and I did continue on it.
And I was not good in history in school simply because I didn't understand the importance of it.
But when I got to C, I did understand the importance of it, and I started studying history.
Another subject I was not good in in school was English.
Here again, I did not understand the importance of learning all of the technique involved in English, for example.
Not having understood it, I wasn't good in it.
That's one of the things I did learn in the little time in high school I was there, was to be good in any subject you have to understand the reason for being good in it, the importance of it.
And this mathematics teacher that I had, and also the head of mathematics in that school,
used the students who were particularly good in it to help other students.
And I learned right away that it was a very simple approach to the situation.
You had to learn the basics of all these subjects in order to understand the importance of them, or to even work the problems.
For example, in algebra, as you know, there are certain
basic rules that you must learn.
These are facts which you learn as a basis of solving the problem.
The same thing goes on all through any part of mathematics starting with addition, subtraction, division, multiplication, all of them, all the way up.
And basically all that I had to do was to get the
people that were assigned to me to help to go back and memorize those things you had to memorize.
And that's another thing that I wish I had done in school was realize the importance of memory.
And I didn't realize the importance of memory until I got into high school, really.
The result has been that my memory has always been bad and still is.
Going back to 36 and shortly after the California dock, who do you think was responsible for grooming Joe Kern, turning him in from an A.B.
to a union leader, as far as speaking abilities?
I think the Communist Party was.
Any persons in particular that you...
Well, I remember Roy Hudson, who was very active during all of this.
At that time, he was the head man in the Marine end of the Communist Party.
He was head of the Marine Workers Industrial Union, and I guess that made him the head.
I don't know whether he became head of Marine Workers Industrial Union because he was a communist, or whether he became a communist because he was there.
I don't know what happened.
But he was at the time the head man, and of course he was interested in trying to build the strength of the Communist Party in the marine industry.
In your opinion, did the Communists seek out Joe Curran or vice versa?
They sought out Joe Curran.
Just like they sought out me when they learned that I was in New York.
They sought me out and
tried to influence me on everything that I did.
And they tried to influence Joe on everything that he did.
And it was up to Joe and it was up to me to listen to their pitch and make a decision as to what part of it you could use and what part of it you couldn't use.
When these rebels went out on strike, did you have your union members
obey their picket lines?
This is in the spring strike of 36.
I don't think we did.
I think they told us to stay aboard the ships.
I think this is a decision we made for the radio operators to stay aboard the ship.
And not actively participate in the strike or actively back?
That's right.
In other words, if the ship
And if the ship sailed, we were to sail with it.
This way, we always had communication.
Communication was as important then as it is now.

And I'm sure that that was what we decided to do, although I don't remember the details or the discussions and so forth that led up to this, because we actually went off the ships with the seamen to begin with.
and then decided that this was the wrong tactic for the radio operator, that one man was not going to contribute anything to the ship, to being ashore if the ship was going to sail.
That man was more important aboard the ship, and it turned out that we were the most important man aboard the ship as far as the strike was concerned.
So then your union members kind of passively supported Kieran and his followers?
We don't more than passively supported it.
We were, we supported him with finances.
I assigned our vice president to the, to the group full-time.
That's all he did.
And do you remember this gentleman's name?
Yeah, his name was Roy Pyle.
Why do you think that the spring strike of 36 failed?
Or do you think it failed?
I don't think it failed.
No, I don't think at all it failed.
It built up the understanding of the need for strong union in the industry, made everyone aware of what the conditions were.
and made the seamen aware that if those conditions were ever going to be changed, there had to be a union, which they controlled, the seamen themselves.
How did the Kieran's group get such a large media following?
Well, the media is always interested in any news that there is.
And there were a lot of liberals associated with the newspapers.
Haywood Broon, did he support you at this time?
He surely did.
Do you think he might have been able to give Seaman more newspaper space than they might have under, say, another personality?
No, Haywood Broon really didn't give the Seaman
any newspaper space any more than he would give anyone else.
He wrote some stuff about the situation when it was appropriate for him to do so, but he really didn't change his style in any way.
Haywood Bruin... Did he ever meet with Karen or anything?
Oh yes, yes.
He met with every leader of every union in the
trade union movement.
And he would give his personal help wherever he could.
So he advised Karen at times?
No, I don't think he ever advised anyone.
I don't think he had that.
His role was advising.
His role was speaking to the people, to the mass group.
One of my jobs was to
keep Haywood Bruin in a condition so he could speak to the people, to stay with him when he was invited to speak at meetings, not just of Seaman, but of other trade unions.
This was true with the transport workers in New York.
It was true of the ILGWU in New York.
He spoke at practically every meeting that there was in New York.
He made himself available to speak at these meetings.
And I would say about at least 75% of the time, one of the things that I had to do really was...
